title: Trump Announces He Will Be Issuing A New Immigration Order
text:
Trump Announces He Will Be Issuing A New Immigration Order The original order will be ... by Randy DeSoto February 16, 2017 at 3:29pm Share on Facebook Share Tweet Email Email Print Advertisement - story continues below 
President Donald Trump announced Thursday that his administration will be issuing a new immigration order next week, which will be tailored to the 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeal’s decision preventing the implementation of the order he issued late last month. The original order will be rescinded. 
“We are issuing a new executive action next week that will comprehensively protect our country,” Trump said at a press conference at the White House. 
“The new order is going to be very much tailored to what I consider to be a very bad decision” by the 9th Circuit, the president added. Advertisement - story continues below 
— NBC Bay Area (@nbcbayarea) February 16, 2017 
The Justice Department also filed a brief on Thursday with the 9th Circuit stating an “en banc” hearing with a larger 11 judge panel will no longer be necessary. 
The brief stated, in part, “(r)ather than continuing this litigation, the President intends in the near future to rescind the order and replace it with a new, substantially revised executive order to eliminate what the [9th Circuit] panel erroneously thought were constitutional concerns.” Advertisement - story continues below New: DOJ tells Ninth Circuit the Trump administration will rescind travel ban order and issue a revised one pic.twitter.com/Albht3hPCx 
— Matt Ford (@fordm) February 16, 2017 
Trump’s revised order will likely expressly address the issue of permanent resident “green cards” holders. 
In its ruling , the 9th Circuit identified the constitutional due process rights of resident non-citizens and current visa holders trying to enter the country as potentially being violated. 
The Trump administration announced shortly after the order came out that residents would be exempted from the 3 month ban, though the order does not state that. Advertisement - story continues below Senate Confirms Fiscal Conservative As Trump’s Budget Director 
The president called the opinion “seriously flawed,” on Thursday and noted what he believed was a major flaw in a tweet after the decision was issued: LAWFARE: "Remarkably, in the entire opinion, the panel did not bother even to cite this (the) statute." A disgraceful decision! 
— Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) February 10, 2017 
Earlier this month, Massachusetts’ based federal district judge Nathaniel Gorton (whose jurisdiction lies in the 1st Circuit) found the president used the statutory authority Congress granted him regarding non-citizen entry into the country for the stated reason of ensuring “that resources are available to review screening procedures and that adequate standards are in place to protect against terrorist attacks.” 
Therefore Gorton ruled, in “light of the ‘plenary congressional power to make polices and rules for exclusion of aliens … which pursuant to 8 U.S.C. 1182(f), has been delegated to the president, the court concludes that the government’s reasons, as provided in the [executive order], are facially legitimate and bona fide.” What do you think?
